Package uk.ac.ed.epcc.webapp.jdbc.filter

Filter interface definitions which are ways of selecting a set of objects/records from a Factory/table.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AcceptFilter<T>
    A Filter that accepts objects based on a Java method
    BaseFilter<T>
    Base Interface for all Filter types.
    BaseSQLFilter<T>
    Base Interface for Filters that select objects via SQL.
    BinaryFilter<T>
    a BaseFilter that encodes a true/false value.
    FilterMatcher<T>
    An interface for an object that can test if a filter matches a specific object.
    FilterVisitor<X,T>
    A visitor for BaseFilter.
    JoinFilter<T>
    Interface for filters that add an explicit join clause.
    OrderClause
    Encapsulation of a clause from a SQL ORDER BY statment.
    OrderFilter<T>
    A SQLFilter that also requests a particular order for the results.
    PatternArgument
    Encodes the arguments to a PreparedStatement for a select clause.
    PatternFilter<T>
    Type of filter that specifies the SQL using parameterised query These should implement as working #hashCode() and #equals(Object)
    ResultMapper<O>
    Interface for classes that map ResultSets to Objects Where Filters are used to define which database records are to be selected a ResultMapper defines what data is to retrieved from these records and how it is to be converted into a domain object.
    ResultVisitor<T>
    Interface for classes that visit the results of an iterator as they are produced
    SQLFilter<T>
    SQLFilter is a marker interface Filters where ALL the selection is performed in SQL only.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractAcceptFilter<T>
    An abstract class for implementing AcceptFilter.
    AndAcceptFilter<T>
    A simple AND combination of AcceptFilters.
    AndFilter<T>
    Combining filter that selects the intersection of multiple filters.
    BaseCombineFilter<T>
    Base class for Filters than combines multiple SQL filters.
    BaseSQLCombineFilter<T>
    Combining filter that is pure SQL.
    BinaryAcceptFilter<T>
    A wrapper that converts a BinaryFilter to an AcceptFilter This is essentially just a cast operation to allow any BinaryFilter to be used where and AcceptFilter is required visitors will usually treat as a binary filter
    CheckEmptyVisitor<T>
    A FilterVisitor that returns true only if the filter is known to match no records without running a SQL query
    ConstPatternArgument<T>
    A constant value PatternArgument.
    ConvertPureAcceptFilterVisitor<T>
    Convert a BaseFilter to a pure AcceptFilter.
    ConvertToAcceptFilter<T>
    A wrapper that converts any BaseFilter into an AcceptFilter using a FilterMatcher.
    DualFilter<T>
    A composite of an AcceptFilter and a SQLFilter.
    FalseFilter<T>
    A filter than never slects any records.
    FilterConverter<T>
    Helper classes to convert generic filters into SQLFilters.
    FilterFinder<T,O>
    Class to create single items specified by a filter and ResultMapper.
    FilterMaker<T,O>
    Class to create single items specified by a filter and ResultMapper.
    FilterReader<T,O>
    common base for classes that generate results via SQL.
    FilterSelect<T>
    Base class that holds the rules for turning filters into SQL selections.
    FilterSet<T>
    Abstract class for a set of Filters This class performs type checking.
    GenericBinaryFilter<T>
    BaseFilter that select true/false.
    GetListFilterVisitor<T>
    a FilterVisitor that extracts any PatternArguments needed by the filter.
    MakeSelectVisitor<T>
    A FilterVisitor that makes the select clause for a filter
    NotAcceptFilter<T extends DataObject>
    A Negating filter that works with any base filter.
    OrFilter<T>
    A generic combining filter that can combine both BaseSQLFilters and AcceptFilters in an OR combination.
    ResultIterator<O>
    Iterator over filter results
    SetMaker<F,O>  
    SQLAndFilter<T>
    SQL only version of AndFilter It can combine PatternFilters.
    SQLNotFilter<Q>
    Invert the sense of a SQLFilter
    SQLOrFilter<T>
    Combine SQL filters using an OR expression Its only safe to use an OR combination with pure SQL
    SQLResultIterator<T,O>
    Iterator over filter results based on the SQL parts of a filter * For large queries the results are generated in batches to reduce memory use.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    FilterCombination
    An Enumeration of the different types of filter combination.
    MatchCondition
    Different types of comparison operation.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    CannotUseSQLException
    Exception thrown when a requested operation cannot be performed via SQL
    NoAcceptFilterException
    Exception that indicates a filter cannot be converted to an AcceptFilter
    NoSQLFilterException
    Exception that indicates a filter cannot be converted to a SQLFilter This covers both the case where the expression cannot be implemented in SQL and when a FilterProvider has insufficient information to generate the filter and a fall-back algorithm is required.

Package uk.ac.ed.epcc.webapp.jdbc.filter Description

Filter interface definitions which are ways of selecting a set of objects/records from a Factory/table. All filters inherit from BaseFilter.

There are a number of different filter types corresponding to different ways of selecting objects. The majority are concerned with filtering at the SQL level though the AcceptFilter filters objects after they have been retrieved from the database.

The basic model of a SQL query we use is: 

SELECT target FROM table 
     [ JOIN table ON join-condition ]*
     WHERE
      [ select-conditions ]+ 
      [ order-by ]?

The various clauses (most importantly the select conditions) are represented by filters implementing one of the various interfaces. Normally we only need very simple filters selecting on a single table field. These can then be composed into more complex expressions using the composition classes in this package.

Filters that operate purely in SQL should implement SQLFilter to indicate this fact. Only SQLFilters can reliably be used with more advanced SQL features like LIMIT clauses or COUNT. The interfaces SQLFilter and AcceptFilter have incompatible method signatures to prevent any class implementing them both.

This package is essentially stand-alone compared to the rest of the framework as it only interacts via interfaces defined in this package.

The visitor pattern is used by filters. Each class can only accept one method from the visitor class so usually filters can only implement one of the interfaces. The exception to this is the composition filters that implement multiple interfaces and have their own explicit accept method indicating that they need special treatment. These are defined as representing the intersection of the behaviours of their different interfaces. The basic filters should only implement one of the interfaces, Where possible the use of AcceptFilter should be avoided. Note that OR combinations of SQL and accept-filters are particularly expensive as the SQL branches of the combined query need to be converted to accept filters that will require an additional query per record to evaluate.

All filters are generic with the type they select and implement Targetted so that these checks can also be performed at run-time. Though only AcceptFilter has other methods whose signature uses the target type.
